posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked:
My team is currently debating about what motor system we want to use this season. We have used NEO Vortexes the past two years and enjoyed using them. This year we would also like to explore what Krakens have, especially the X44. However, our programmers are relatively inexperienced and we don’t know how majorly the change would affect them.

How different are the two systems? Is switching just as simple as changing a few lines of the code?

Is there a way for us to experiment with using Krakens without purchasing Phoenix 6? (We have two unused krakens in our lab for some reason)

And, in your opinion, which software system is easier to use?

Hermes8942:

Is there a way for us to experiment with using Krakens without purchasing Phoenix 6? (We have two unused krakens in our lab for some reason)

You can use the motors and phoenix 6 without purchasing anything. Phoenix pro is only for a select few features like FOC but the motor is completely usable without it.

Hermes8942:

And, in your opinion, which software system is easier to use?

imo it’s equivalent or even easier to use rev software until you need to uses an advanced feature like on board motion profiling in which CTRE does it better

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked:
Hermes8942:

purchasing Phoenix 6

As the person above me said too, phoenix 6 is completely free. Phoenix pro is the license you can purchase that unlocks some nice to have but unnecessary features.

posts.name: James O’Leary
posts.cooked: There’s a lot of nice QOL things that we found with krakens that vortexes and neos don’t have. Not having to plug into each motor controller was really nice, the debugging was a lot easier on CTRE hardware than Rev, integrated motor controller was nice(i know vortexes have something similar) and ring terminals for Power and CAN . In short, if y’all have the money do it.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
We never used the NEO Vortexes, but we did use the original NEO/SparkMax combo before Falcon 500 (and subsequently Kraken) was released. In general, our programmers far prefer the CTRE environment and we do use it both with motion profiling as well as integration with AdvantageKit. In fact, in 2024 (before X44 and Minion were released) we had a pair of NEO550s on the robot for some small mechanisms and they were nagging me constantly to switch them over to something that ran on CTRE code (which ultimately proved impractical at the time, but still).

On the hardware-side, we’ve been very happy with our experience with Krakens, and have had no major issues with them. The handful of issues we did have were resolved very quickly by their support team.

And speaking of support, that’s one other thing I’ll add, CTRE has excellent support. Our programming team has spent many (productive) hours on the phone with them working out different issues and functions with our code and they’ve always been happy to help, even sometimes after normal business hours (you’d swear these guys never go home).

posts.name: Tio
posts.cooked: For Swerve Drive, get all CTRE motors and electronics just because the Swerve generator. You will have your robot driving in no time.

posts.name: Carter Ryba
posts.cooked:
SparkMAX’s/Vortex’s are technically easier to program, however, Krakens are a better experience. Phoenix Tuner X is like 3x better than Rev Hardware Client, but that’s only because you can connect wirelessly and the UI looks cool.

IMO just use the motors you have AND buy some krakens. At the very least buy krakens for swerve so you can use the CTRE swerve gen because it makes so everything easy. (Especially for inexperienced programmers)

I’m very partial to krakens because we had not a single issue with them on our bot this year.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
My team tends to prefer the CTRE products over the Rev products. - they are competitors, though.

If you like, you can compare our template for settings on the SparkMax with settings on the TalonFX. 2025-Summer-Robot-4237/src/main/java/frc/robot/motors at main · SirLanceABot/2025-Summer-Robot-4237 · GitHub

About the only tricky thing I had to learn was what happens when you change one setting on the SparkMax vs changing one setting on the TalonFX.

The  TalonFX changes all the settings at once so if you want to change just one setting you have to refresh the other settings so they aren’t lost. Change the one setting you want then apply all of the settings again.

There may be better code to accomplish what we want and it would be cleaner and simpler code to set everything at once but we like to do one at a time to easily notice and redo if there are errors making a setting.

posts.name: Zac Ogburn
posts.cooked:
We used just neos in the 2024 season, and a mix of neos and krakens in the 2025 season. For the 2026 season, we’re trying to see if we have the budget to move to 100% krakens. I can’t speak from a programming standpoint, but from a mechanical standpoint, krakens are 1000% the way to go. Packaging and placing them in the robot is SO much easier. No pesky motor controller or fragile encoder cables to worry about. We fried 5 neos this past season due to an encoder cable getting damaged. Krakens are overall far more robust, no need to worry about a machine key slipping out due to their spline shaft. It’s also MUCH harder to overheat a kraken. Not to mention that the overall performance of a kraken is objectively superior to a neo 1.1 or vortex.

If you can go kraken, do it.

posts.name: Matt Middleton
posts.cooked: Vortexes will still be in our “quiver” for specific applications where we want to leverage its through-shaft capability.  However, for pretty much every other use case we’ll employ Krakens - either X60 or X44.

posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked:
As others said, Phoenix 6 is free, Honestly if your programmers are inexperienced you really shouldn’t have to purchase phoenix pro until you think you need and can utilize well some of the features.

Disclaimer: we are a rev team, I’m a lot more experienced with that ecosystem. Overall I think for basic tasks they aren’t going to be too different difficulty wise, I think the more advanced you get programming wise the more ctre is gonna take the lead. On board PID and Motion profiling and the simulation stuff they have (Rev has this too but afaik ctre’s is better) can be really useful.

Obviously there will still definetely be a transition but nothing crazy.

Or you could just switch to redux motors only ¯_(ツ)_/¯.

posts.name: Graham Howard
posts.cooked:
Gavin0:

On board PID and Motion profiling and the simulation stuff they have (Rev has this too but afaik ctre’s is better) can be really useful.

As far as I know you’re a little outdated- I think REV and CTRE have near simulation parity, REV has had PID on board for years , and they’re getting proper motion profiling this season (see feedforward thread)!

posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked:
Yeah you’re completely right.

REV has had PID on board for years

We’ve literally been using this for so long idk why I said that .

Either way one thing i forgot to mention: The general consensus from what I can tell is that ctre has a lot better documentation for the software side of things, take that as you will

posts.name: Ainesh Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: It went pretty good for my team. I wasn’t extremely involved in the process of switching, but we did a staggered approach where we did a mix of Neos and Krakens in 2024 and switched to almost all Krakens (used falcons where Krakens weren’t really necessary). Also from what I’ve heard from my teams programmers, they find using Krakens much easier than using Neos for coding, but take that with a grain of salt because I’m not that familiar with how the switch went on the programming side.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
REVLib is getting closer in feature parity with Phoenix 6, so I don’t think there will be a huge benefit software-wise choosing one or the other (though I think Phoenix 6 is still a more fleshed-out API, especially with respect to their Swerve API)

A noticeable change between kraken and Neo is the hardware. SplineXS has benefits over the keyed shaft of neos (even load, rather than transferring at the keyway), but in my opinion the biggest benefit of krakens is the wiring. The screw terminals are second to none, since you can make the wires the correct length each season without having an intermediary connector (failure point). In 2025 we had direct runs to all of our motors. The motor controller being integrated means you don’t need to find room to mount a separate controller. With 8 motors in a swerve chassis alone, it made a huge difference when we converted our 2024 robot with a 24” drive base from Neos to falcons. A lot of room on the belly pan was opened up
With vortex’s and sparkflex’s this benefit can exist too. I am envious of your bellypan space!

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
JamesO1086:

Not having to plug into each motor controller was really nice

We continue to use both REV and CTRE motor controllers every year, and one of our biggest frustrations has always been the lack of a direct USB connection on the TalonFX. Configuration over the network is occasionally useful, but not having an easy way to load firmware and configure CAN IDs directly from a laptop is really frustrating. With the SparkMax/Flex, we can configure every device before it’s even mounted on the robot (or have a replacement pre-configured when swapping in the pits). Needing to manually blink each device and deconflict CAN IDs once the devices are already mounted is not a fun experience, especially under time pressure…

posts.name: James O’Leary
posts.cooked: We haven’t had any issues with configuring talons, but spark maxes have been a pain for us, hardware and software. We went through 2 spark maxes and neos before our week 1 and found Krakens were a lot easier to debug for us specifically. We made the full swap between vapor and chcmp and it was really good for us at least but I do see the advantages of Sparkflexes.

posts.name: Virendrasinh Vaghela
posts.cooked:
Very good experience. (10/10)

Observation is Kraken with Chassis makes it very reliable for Auto, Mechanisms can still be driven using Neos if you have an extra. Canivor Keeps CAN easy from chassis to subsystem.

posts.name: Philip
posts.cooked: We only use Talons and our spares are all preconfigured if they are attached to mechanisms which allows us to not need to do anything in pit. Additionally, when we used rev the can bus is not always available in the client. I don’t know why but sometimes it took multiple tries to get access to the bus. Also if you want to not need with conflicting, you can preset the ids to not conflict and set them on a separate environment while build is doing the mechanical swap.

data.fancy_title: Teams that switched from NEOs to Krakens, how did it go?
data.title: Teams that switched from NEOs to Krakens, how did it go?
